World Cup

FIFA president Gianni Infantino has received a letter signed by over 90 civil society groups, the majority of which are based in the United States, expressing “deep concern” about immigration policies and enforcement measures in the U.S. and their potential impact on the World Cup in 2026.

The letter urges FIFA to use its “influence” to call on the administration of President Donald Trump to guarantee the fundamental rights of the millions of football fans who will seek to attend the World Cup next summer. The groups reference Infantino's “high-profile engagements” in the White House and his recent trip to Saudi Arabia and Qatar, when he accompanied President Trump at an investment summit as evidence of his proximity to the U.S. President.

Advertisement

The letter asks FIFA to leverage its position to “publicly” urge President Trump to reverse policies and practices that the groups say pose risks to both foreign tournament attendees and migrant communities living within the U.S. The letter goes on to warn that if FIFA continues to remain silent, then “the FIFA brand will be used as a public relations tool to whitewash the reputation of an increasingly authoritarian government.”

The letter says: “We call on FIFA to use its influence to encourage the U.S. government to guarantee the fundamental rights of the millions of foreign visitors and fans who seek entry to the U.S. to attend the tournaments, and those of the constitutional rights of the many immigrants who already live, work, and contribute meaningfully to the cities selected to host them.”

The letter, which has been seen by The Athletic, is co-signed by groups including Human Rights Watch, Amnesty International and NAACP, an American civil rights organization founded in 1909, as well as the 105-year-old American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU). Civil society groups and unions based in New York, Florida, Georgia, California, Texas, Massachusetts, Missouri, Pennsylvania, all states which will host World Cup fixtures, have signed the letter.

The letter was co-ordinated by the British advocacy group Fair Square, in collaboration with several of the signatories. It was sent to FIFA on the morning of July 1, addressed to Infantino and copying in senior officials including Carlos Cordeiro, the former U.S. Soccer president who now serves as an advisor to Infantino. The letter was also copied into the FIFA COO Kevin Lamour, its World Cup COO Heimo Schirgi, as well as its  director of government relations Alex Sopko and chief strategy officer Amy Hopfinger. The letter also copied in Matthew Mullen, the FIFA Head of Human Rights specifically for the World Cup, in 2026, which will be co-hosted by the U.S., Canada and Mexico.

Advertisement

Minky Worden, the director of global initiatives at Human Rights Watch, told The Athletic this type of intervention is “very uncommon in the context of any U.S. mega-sporting event”, which underlines the concern felt by the signatories about the current climate in the U.S.

The letter points to the series of executive orders and policy changes implemented by President Trump since his inauguration in 2025. The administration argues these orders are in the interests of national security and public safety.

In their letter, however, the rights groups say they are concerned for the projected 2.6 million visitors projected to attend the World Cup in 2026.

The letter says: “Increased immigration enforcement actions, abusive Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) operations, and broader border restrictions have also contributed to widespread fear and uncertainty. Several foreign governments have already issued travel advisories to its citizens, warning of risks of being denied entry or detained and deported when traveling to the U.S.”

There has been evidence of reduced inbound travel to the U.S., with Republican congressman Darin LaHood last week expressing concern about a 40 per cent reduction in travel to the U.S. from Canada amid a trade war, while he added that tourism in Las Vegas, New York and Florida is down.

The letter points to the imposition of travel bans by the Trump administration against nationals from twelve countries, which threatens to exclude Iranian football fans from the World Cup, as their team has already qualified for the tournament, as well as partial restrictions on seven more nations including Venezuela, who are in contention to qualify. The groups also reference reporting from the New York Times, which claimed that 36 more countries, many of which are African, could be added to the list.

Advertisement

The letter warns that “spectators from other countries remain subject to invasive and burdensome vetting procedures and the possibility of being denied travel authorization or entry due to their political or religious views.”

The groups also point to concerns about the alleged “cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment” within U.S. immigration detention facilities.

The letter says that the success of a World Cup depends not only on infrastructure and logistics, but also the “spirit of openness and safety extended to all who participate and attend”.

Infantino insisted at the FIFA Congress in May that the world is welcome in America, saying in Paraguay: “Of course, the players, of course, everyone involved, all of us, but definitely also all the fans.”

The U.S. vice-president J.D. Vance said in May: “Of course everyone is welcome to come and see this wonderful event. We want them to come, we want them to celebrate, we want them to watch the games.

“But when the time is up we want them to go home, otherwise they will have to talk to Secretary Noem,” he continued, referring to Kristi Noem, the Secretary of Homeland Security.

The letter argues that FIFA, in accordance with its own Human Rights Policy, has a “responsibility to act.”

The letter says: “The policy specifically identifies that ‘providing for the safety and security of people who are attending or are otherwise involved in or affected by FIFA's events may impact certain fundamental human rights, such as freedom of movement, expression and assembly' as one of FIFA's five salient human rights risks.”

It continues: “People of all nationalities should be able to travel to the United States without fear of arbitrary denial of entry, arbitrary detention, or deportation without due process, and people in the United States should be able to exercise their right to freedom of expression without fear of arbitrary detention and deportation, and migrant communities should not live in perpetual fear of CBP and ICE raids.”

The CBP provoked alarm before this summer's FIFA Club World Cup when it posted on Facebook that its agents would be “suited and booted ready to provide security for the first round of games.”

The Athletic revealed that the post was removed after direct contact from senior personnel at FIFA expressing concerns, but it is not clear as to the extent to which FIFA's outreach impacted the decision.

NBC Miami reported that ICE confirmed that they would be present at games as part of the security operation, while also including a reminder that non-American citizens should carry proof of their legal status. Attendances for the Club World Cup have been mixed, with some matches close to full and some leaving tens of thousands of seats empty.

Advertisement

FIFA, which has been approached for comment about the letter to Infantino, has faced numerous questions over its commitment to human rights after holding its previous two men's World Cups in Qatar and Russia, while the 2034 edition will be held in Saudi Arabia. Eleven leading human rights organisations have previously criticised a 39-page document published by the world football governing body FIFA by the Saudi arm of the global law firm Clifford Chance. The groups claimed it represented a “flawed” assessment of Saudi Arabia as the country bid to host the World Cup.

FIFA is currently hiring for a Head of Human Rights & Anti-Discrimination, according to a job posting on its webpage. The posting says the applicant must have 10 years experience as a human rights executive, must demonstrate high ethical standards and personal integrity, and have experience working with marginalized and vulnerable people. Among the key tasks will be to ensure the active and transparent communication of FIFA's human rights work.

(Top photo: Win McNamee/Getty Images)

Adam Crafton  is a British journalist based in New York City, having relocated from London in 2024. He primarily covers soccer for The Athletic. In 2024, he was named the Sports Writer of the Year by the Sports' Journalist Association, after winning the Young Sports Writer of the Year award in 2018. Follow Adam on Twitter @AdamCrafton_

Title: Real Madrid vs Juventus: FIFA Club World Cup stats & head-to-head

Real Madrid face Juventus in last 16

Winners will face either Borussia Dortmund or Monterrey

Get Involved: #bbcfootball, via WhatsApp on 03301231826 or text 81111 (UK only, standard message rates apply)

Michael Emons

Real Madrid 0-0 Juventus

Thibaut Courtois has to come out of his area and head the ball clear after he and team-mate Antonio Rudiger had got in each other's way with an attempted first clearance.

Real Madrid 0-0 Juventus

Federico Valverde almost scored at the end of the first half and has almost scored at the start of the second half. Jude Bellingham, under pressure and closely marked, gives it to the Real captain, who shoots across goal but just wide of the far post.

Real Madrid 0-0 Juventus

And the second half is under way. Remember, extra-time and penalties are both still possible.

Real Madrid 0-0 Juventus

It's raining at the start of the second half, but no lightning anywhere near the stadium so far so we're ready to go.

The rain might be quite welcome in the sweltering conditions in Miami. It has just gone 4pm local time.

Real Madrid 0-0 Juventus

The winner of this tie will take on either Borussia Dortmund or Monterrey of Mexico in the quarter-final on 5 July.

Dortmund and Monterrey start their last-16 tie at 02:00 BST on Wednesday.

Real Madrid 0-0 Juventus

Expect Michele di Gregorio's wonderful one-handed save to deny Federico Valverde on a loop and to see it again and again during the half-time break.

That has been the best moment of the match by some way, although Jude Bellingham also came close, only to see a shot cleared off the line by Daniele Rugani.

Apart from that, not much to get excited about in the Miami heat.

Real Madrid 0-0 Juventus

The ball is headed back by Juventus and it nearly fell for Real captain Federico Valverde, although he couldn't capitalise as he missed the attempted header.

Real Madrid 0-0 Juventus

Real are ending the half strongly. Trent Alexander-Arnold fizzes a low cross from the right and it causes panic among the Juventus defence, but no Real player can get a touch.

Real Madrid 0-0 Juventus

It's a really good, strong left hand and a decent save. Decent strike initially too from Valverde.

Real Madrid 0-0 Juventus

Arda Guler shows a great piece of skill to take a pass on the chest and then lift the ball over Francisco Conceicao although his cross is then cut out.

Then, as we move into injury time, Real's Federico Valverde creates the best moment of the match with a fine strike from 30 yards. Michele di Gregorio does superbly to fling himself to his left and at full stretch get a hand to the ball to push it around the post.

Probably the best two bits of action in the space of a few minutes.

Real Madrid 0-0 Juventus

Bright from Juventus' Khephren Thuram as he shows a fine burst of pace to gets some space down the left, only for his cross to be headed away at the near post by Aurelien Tchouameni.

Real Madrid 0-0 Juventus

Michael BrownFormer Premier League midfielder on Dazn

That was a quality ball in. He'll be disappointed to have got nothing on that because he's got a long time to look at it. Another opportunity wasted. 

Real Madrid 0-0 Juventus

Arda Guler looks to provide some inspiration with a whipped in cross, but Real's Aurelien Tchouameni misjudges the header and can't get a touch on the delivery to send it goalwards.

Real Madrid 0-0 Juventus

It has not been a great half of football, summed up with Juventus overhitting a cross from the left. We've already seen three of the six last-16 ties go to extra-time and that's what we'll have if it's level at 90 minutes.

We're yet to have a penalty shootout yet in this tournament? Is today the day?

Real Madrid 0-0 Juventus

As we have got used to in this tournament, there is a cooling break at the 30-minute mark as the players desperately get a drink of water in the stifling conditions.

Real Madrid 0-0 Juventus

We haven't mentioned Jude Bellingham much, until now. The England man is in the six-yard box and has a strike which is partially saved by a foot of Michele di Gregorio with team-mate Daniele Rugani doing the rest and clearing it off the line. 

Real Madrid 0-0 Juventus

Michael BrownFormer Premier League midfielder on Dazn

Yildiz has just said "whenever you give me the ball, I'm going to try and do something".

The way he shifts it both ways is impressive. 

Real Madrid 0-0 Juventus

Real quickly earn a second corner and this time it goes short to Vinicius Jr, but, unmarked from 25 yards out, all he can do is drag it harmlessly off target.

Real Madrid 0-0 Juventus

Aurelien Tchouameni has a strike from 25 yards for Real, but it is deflected wide for Real's first corner.

The outswinger eventually finds Dean Huijsen and the ex-Bournemouth man puts too much on the cross back into the danger zone.

Real Madrid 0-0 Juventus

A chance for Juventus as the ball is played in from the left to Francisco Conceicao, but the header lacks the power or direction to trouble Thibaut Courtois, who make a routine stop.

Title: The Best Game of the Club World Cup so Far: Takeaways From Man City 3–4 Al Hilal
Description:
Al Hilal defeated Manchester City in the FIFA Club World Cup round of 16 in one of the biggest upsets of the tournament. An upset that followed another major upset earlier in the day as Fluminense eliminated Inter Milan.

Man City dominated the first half after Bernardo Silva opened the scoring. They limited Al Hilal to half-chances for the first 45, but the second half was a completely different tale. Marcos Leonardo and Malcom each scored while Erling Haaland kept the Cityzens in the tie to force extra time. Three more goals in extra time with both sides trading blows produced one of the best ties of the summer. 

Leonardo's 112th minute goal was the decider in the end as Simone Inzaghi's side pulled off the upset. Redemption for Inzaghi in some way after losing the Champions League final back in 2023 against Guardiola, but belief is building within the Al Hilal camp that they can make a real run this tournament. Fluminense await in the next round, but they'll celebrate this win before preparing for the quarterfinals.

One of the best games of the Club World Cup is in the books, but the excitement continues to build as we near the decisive stages of the tournament.

Takeaways from the game below.

The entire story tells a much different tale, but the first half was extremely dominant from Man City. It was a vintage showing from a Pep Guardiola side as they methodically maintained possession and bided their time every time they were on the ball. Play was shifted wide, back-and-forth as Savinho and Jeremy Doku looked to find a killer pass. They were cruising... until the second half.

If the Manchester City that showed up in the first half kept on, their status as favorites would've been cemented. Instead, the second half and extra time told a different tale. The Man City we saw for a majority of the night that what fans saw last year in the Premier League and Champions League. They were unable to dominate for the majority of the night and it cost them.

Tijjani Reijnders and Rayan Ait-Nouri look to be some of the best signings of the summer, not to mention Rayan Cherki's contribution off the bench.

Phil Foden wasn't himself last season. A goal-scoring drought, in and out of starting lineups, he never quite looked like his best. This summer? He was a contender for player of the tournament if they advanced.

Foden's goal at the end of the first half of extra time was clutch and a showcase of his technical ability. On talk of Man City's summer business, Foden's reemergence could end up being the biggest story of the summer. Particularly in the wake of Kevin De Bruyne's departure. Whether Guardiola decides to insert him specifically into the No. 10 role, or play him on the flanks where he can be lethal, Foden could play a major part in Man City's return to the title picture. 

What an opportunity for Al Hilal and Simone Inzaghi in just his first month in charge. Al Hilal certainly weren't favored coming into the game, but fans counting them out didn't see value their performance against Real Madrid in the group stage.

After dispatching one of the tournament favorites, Al Hilal face off against Cinderella story Fluminense. While neutrals might've fantasized about an opportunity to see Inzaghi face off against his former club, he can put those nerves to bed thanks to El Flu.

They have the belief in them now after defeating Man City. Al Hilal vs. Fluminense will be one of the most exciting games of the tournament as two underdog sides look to book their spot in the final four.

Title: Inter and Man City Crashed Out in FIFA Club World Cup Last 16
Description:
Inter Milan and Manchester City were surprisingly knocked out of the FIFA Club World Cup last 16 round. The Nerazzurri were beaten 2-0 by Fluminense, while Man City were stunned 4-3 by Al Hilal in extra time.

La Beneamata's search for a trophy ended in woe again following their elimination in the FIFA Club World Cup tournament. Christian Chivu's team crashed out in the last 16 after suffering a 2-0 defeat against Brazilian side Fluminense.

Keen on advancing into the next round, the Nerazzurri found themselves in trouble soon after kick-off as their opponent immediately went a goal up. Renato Gaucho's side went ahead after just three minutes of play through German Cano.

That early goal gives Fluminense a tactical advantage as they can absorb Inter's pressure and play more on the break. Despite the Italian side's flurry of attacking attempts, Fluzao managed to hold on tight before eventually securing their victory with a second goal, netted by Hercules deep in stoppage time.

In another tie, Manchester City were also experiencing a similar result as Inter during their CWC last 16 tie against Al Hilal. Pep Guardiola's side saw their journey in the tournament end earlier than expected, despite dominating the game and getting an early lead.

Man City went one goal up during the first 45 minutes through Bernardo Silva after just nine minutes of play. However, City's failure to convert their chances in that first half cost them dearly in the end.

Al Hilal bounced back in the second half as they turned things around with goals from Marcos Leonardo and Malcom. Man City managed to draw level with a goal from Erling Haaland, making the scoreline 2-2 in regular time.

Despite their enormous pressure during the 2×15 period, Man City continue to struggle defensively against Al Hilal's counterattack. Simone Inzaghi's men went on to shock everyone as they scored two more goals in extra time.

Kalidou Koulibaly and Leonardo's second gave Al Hilal that surprise result as City only managed to score one back from Phil Foden's effort. It was another disappointing outcome for Man City, who, just like Inter, failed to win any trophy this past season.

Title: John Isner picks the American male tennis player he is most excited about and has the best chance to win Wimbledon
Description:
American men's players continue their search for an elusive Grand Slam title this month, hoping to be the one to end the drought.

Former ATP number one Andy Roddick represents the last American man to win a Grand Slam title, having triumphed at the US Open in 2003.

Pete Sampras meanwhile is the last American man to win Wimbledon, which is currently underway in London.

Sampras was successful at Wimbledon in 2000, when he won the grass court Grand Slam for the fourth successive year.

The nation's hopes of further success are now falling on a handful of players, namely Taylor Fritz, Ben Shelton, Frances Tiafoe and Tommy Paul.

And speaking on Tennis Channel, former American professional John Isner has now shared which of his compatriots he is most excited about on the ATP Tour.

Isner commented: “I think the one who excites me the most is probably Ben Shelton. His game is so huge.

“He might take some early first round losses, which we saw in Queen's and Mallorca to Lerner Tien, but he picks up his level when the stage is big, so I expect him to play very well at Wimbledon.

READ MORE: Learner Tien makes American tennis history after beating Ben Shelton in Mallorca

“Once he can get his feet wet in the tournament he is a crazy tough out because he plays with such flair and confidence. He has such a big game, his serve is ridiculous. He is so athletic.

“I think Ben Shelton in my mind is the guy that has probably the best chance to break through in a huge event like Wimbledon in the next three to five years.”

Shelton has enjoyed superb progress on the ATP Tour this season, having recently broken the top 10 for the first time in his career.

But he remains behind Fritz in that regard, with the 2024 US Open runner-up currently fifth in the ATP rankings.

READ MORE: The next most likely American to win a Grand Slam following Ben Shelton's top 10 debut 

It is, however, European players who dominate the standings, with Italian Jannik Sinner at the very top of the pile.

He is followed by Spaniard Carlos Alcaraz and German Alexander Zverev in second and third respectively, with Briton Jack Draper in fourth.

And unfortunately for the American men, their European counterparts continue to dominate the sport as Wimbledon gets underway.

Moreover, their female counterparts are doing their lack of success no favours, with Americans Madison Keys and Coco Gauff winning the 2025 Australian Open and French Open respectively.

Fritz has come the closest to ending the painful men's drought in recent times, having lost last year's US Open final to Sinner.

And Shelton also produced a valiant effort at the 2025 Australian Open, but once again it was the world number one who ended his hopes, this time in the semi-finals.

Also excited about Shelton is Brad Gilbert, but Jimmy Connors favours Tommy Paul for Wimbledon success over him and Fritz.

Title: Wimbledon LIVE: BBC commentator in tears as McEnroe calls for player to never return
Description:
Wimbledon got off to a cracking start on day one with several fantastic storylines developing. A number of big upsets took place and there was another one at the start of day two. Jessica Pegula, the third seed, was sensationally dumped out by Italian youngster Elisabetta Cocciaretto. There was another huge shock in the evening as Coco Gauff fell in straight sets at the hands of Dayana Yastremska.

There was no such misfortune for Jack Draper, who breezed into the second round after Sebastian Baez was forced to retire through injury. Dan Evans and Jack Pinnington Jones also secured victories on another brilliant day for the British contingent at SW19. As things stand, a total of 10 home players have made it through to round two.

You can follow all the action in Express Sport's LIVE blog below...

Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions, and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. Read our Privacy Policy

We use your sign-up to provide content in ways you've consented to and to improve our understanding of you. This may include adverts from us and 3rd parties based on our understanding. You can unsubscribe at any time. Read our Privacy Policy

Minutes after No. 2 seed Coco Gauff suffered a shock first-round exit on Court 1, the men's 18th seed Ugo Humbert has gone out of the tournament.

Veteran Frenchman Gael Monfils caused a huge upset over five sets. And you could hear the cheers all the way on Centre Court - even through the closed roof. Here's the updated list of seeds to go out on day two.

MEN'S

7th seed Lorenzo Musetti

30th seed Alex Michelsen

27th seed Denis Shapovalov

28th seed Alexander Bublik

3rd seed Alexander Zverev

18th seed Ugo Humbert

WOMEN'S

3rd seed Jessica Pegula

26th seed Marta Kostyuk

5th seed Qinwen Zheng

15th seed Karolina Muchova

25th seed Magdalena Frech

27th seed Magda Linette

2nd seed Coco Gauff

No messing about from Dayana Yastremska - she had Coco Gauff in trouble and she has capitalised in ruthless fashion to win 7-5 6-1.

Yastremska was buoyed by her win in the first-set tiebreak and only ramped up the pressure on Gauff in the second.

A huge scalp on a day which has seen three of the top-five seeds crash out of the women's draw.



The roof has just shut on Centre Court with Novak Djokovic and Alexandre Muller level at one-set all.

It's still about more than half-full on Wimbledon's biggest showcourt, even though the fans here have been watching more than seven hours' worth of tennis.

They let out a loud cheer when the floodlights were switched on, bathing the court in a warm glow.

Coco Gauff is well and truly on the rops on Court 1.

The second seed is one game away from crashing out of Wimbledon in startling circumstances.

Dayana Yastremska won the first set via a tiebreak and she is now 5-1 up in the second set.

It would take a miracle for Gauff to bring it back from here.

Incredible scenes on Centre Court as Alexandre Muller wins a lengthy tiebreak to claim the second set against Novak Djokovic!

The veteran Serb had six opportunites to wrap up the set but was made to pay for his mistakes.

It's level heading into set three.



Jack Pinnington Jones is through to the second round on his Wimbledon debut!

The 22-year-old has beaten Tomas Etcheverry in straight sets to wrap up a memorable evening at SW19.

It finishes 6-7 3-6 5-7 in favour of Pinnington Jones, who celebrates with a fist-pump before soaking up the applause of the crowd.

More joy for the Brits on day two!

Carlos Alcaraz has sent a heartwarming message to the poorly fan who needed treatment during his victory over Fabio Fognini.

The fan's daughter wrote on social media: "Thank you for the concern shown to my mum today who was taken ill during your tennis match at Centre Court. Unlikely you'll see this message but I can try!

To her surprise, Alcaraz responded: "You're very welcome, it was nothing!

"I hope your mum is doing well. Send her a kiss from me and take good care of her!"

You\u2019re very welcome, it was nothing! I hope your mum is doing well. Send her a kiss from me and take good care of her! \u2764\ufe0f

John McEnroe has named Jack Draper as one of four players he believes can go all the way at SW19.

Speaking on BBC One, the American said: "Jack Draper is the fourth favourite to win this tournament.

"He could win a major for the first time in his life, this is about dealing with the nerves. That's pressure but it's also a pretty cool feeling.

"I wouldn't pick Draper as my No. 1 [favourite]. I would pick the obvious pick as No. 1 but it's difficult to win three in a row.

"In terms of the favourite, it's a toss-up between Alcaraz and Sinner. Jack might have to beat both of those guys and Novak [Djokovic] and that's the really hard part."



Jack Draper is not putting any thought into his tough road to the later rounds of Wimbledon.

He faces Marin Cilic in the second round after thrashing Sebastian Baez, while he is projected to meet Jakub Mensik in the round of 16, Novak Djokovic in the quarter-finals, Jannik Sinner in the semi-finals and Carlos Alcaraz in the final.

"I can't be thinking five matches ahead," Draper insisted. "Everyone in this draw can play incredible tennis.

"You've got to have respect for every one of these guys. Until I deserve a place in the next round, I'm not there yet."

Novak Djokovic has made a flying start to his opening match against Alexandre Muller.

The veteran Serb only dropped one game on his way to winning the first set.

Muller is up against it and will need to raise his level to get himself back into this contest.

Centre Court ticketholders were expecting to watch Coco Gauff take on Dayana Yastremska in her opening match after Novak Djokovic played tonight.

However, that match has been moved because of lengthy delays on the main show court.

Organisers likely did not expect Gauff and Yastremska to be able to finish tonight after Djokovic and Alexandre Muller stepped onto the court at 7pm, had they remained on Centre.

As a result, Gauff's match has been moved to Court 1, with the pair currently walking out in Gauff's bid claim the Channel Slam after her win in Paris.

Djokovic, meanwhile, has broken Muller for a third time to take the opening set.

Jack Draper showed his class with some kind words for Sebastian Baez in his on-court interview.

"I wanted to play a bit longer, in all honesty," said the young Brit.

"I was getting my tennis together a little bit and I was serving well. It's no way to win like that and I wish Sebastian the best in his recovery, of course.

"I just try and focus on the things I can control. Coming out here, giving my very best and hopefully playing the best tennis I can."



Sebastian Baez has retired in the third set against Jack Draper after losing the first two.

The Argentine suffered a nasty fall earlier in the match and appeared to twist his knee, which required medical attention and a five-minute break in play.

After discussing the injury with two physios, Baez opted to continue playing but could not finish the contest and looked emotional as he left the court.

Draper, who was impressive throughout, next faces Marin Cilic in the second round.

Jack Draper advances to the second round after Sebastian Baez is forced to retire with injury #Wimbledon pic.twitter.com/7XvpBFCnSl

With Alexander Zverev going out in a match that started on day one of the tournament and finished on day two, that's five seeded men and five seeded women who have lost so far on Tuesday.

Seeds out on day two:

MEN'S

7th seed Lorenzo Musetti

30th seed Alex Michelsen

27th seed Denis Shapovalov

28th seed Alexander Bublik

3rd seed Alexander Zverev

WOMEN'S

3rd seed Jessica Pegula

26th seed Marta Kostyuk

5th seed Qinwen Zheng

15th seed Karolina Muchova

25th seed Magdalena Frech

French star Arthur Rinderknech stunned No.3 seed Alexander Zverev in a gruelling, four-hour and 40-minute clash that spanned two days.

The match was suspended at one-set all shortly before the 11pm curfew hit on Monday. World No.72 Rinderknech returned and earned his biggest win ever 7-6(3) 6-7(8) 6-3 6-7(5) 6-4.

Afterwards, he told the Centre Court crowd: “I don't know, I don't even know where to start, start for sure with the crowd because I'm feeling the same way as you guys. I don't know, this woo every time! I'm dying every time you guys are saying woo!

“My legs are still shaking, I can't do it anymore, just so happy the match is finished. We started yesterday, at 8? We finish today at 7. Slept about six hours last night. It's very difficult this sport but, I mean, what a moment. Such emotions.”



Jack Draper made just as little fuss in winning that second set as he did the first one.

Sebastian Baez has been thoroughly outgunned on Court 1 in just about every department.

And we've only been playing for an hour and four minutes.

If the first two are anything to go by, this third set should just be a formality for Britain's number-one hope at this year's tournament.

Sebastian Baez has decided to play on after a five-minute delay and medical treatment to his right knee.

The Argentine, while down 2-1 in the second set, had lengthy conversations with the physios while receiving treatment.

After watching Jack Draper's opponent take a nasty fall, John McEnroe on BBC commentary said: "That didn't feel too good on the let knee. Potentially he could hurt himself further here in a match that he's got about a two per cent to me chance to winning, maybe five at the most.

"Maybe not go through safe so he can play the rest of the year because he needs to get his act together. He doesn't want to injure himself further.

"There's going to be mental pain I feel, but physically you don't want to put yourself out for a couple of months if there is something."



Two-time Wimbledon champion Petra Kvitova played her last-ever match at the All England Club on Tuesday, losing 6-3 6-1 to No.10 seed Emma Navaro.

And the former world No. 2 decided to get on the media intercom system to announce her last press conference. "This is Petra Kvitova," she said, before announcing that she was heading in for her presser.

Another announcement came a few moments later, saying: "That was Petra Kvitova announcing her final press conference in the main media theatre."

Heather Watson has insisted that she has no plans to retire after suffering yet another early Wimbledon exit.

She was beaten by Clara Tauson despite winning the first set, marking the ninth time she has been dumped out in the opening round.

Asked if that might have been her last match at SW19, Watson replied: "Hopefully not. That's not my plan.

"I want to play as long as I'm still playing tournaments like this. I was so grateful for the opportunity when the tournament gave me the wildcard, because this for me is the pinnacle.

"Like when I walked out onto court today, I got a little bit emotional, because it's so special.

"I just appreciate it so much any time I get to be a part of this tournament, so hopefully I've still got a few left in me and I can get there on my own next year."

We've not even been playing for half an hour and Jack Draper is a third of the way to the second round.

He had the beating of Sebastian Baez all ends up there, putting him under pressure both on serve and against it.

It'll be over quickly at this rate, unless Baez finds another gear.

Ella Seidel retired during her match with Jessica Bouzas Maneiro in the second set after falling to the ground in pain.

The German qualifier appeared to twist her ankle and called for a medical time out at the back of the court.

The 20-year-old tried to play on in her first main draw match at Wimbledon, but was unable to continue and ended up conceding.



Jack Draper could hardly have hoped for a better start than this.

The Briton broke Sebastian Baez in the very first game of the match, and he's just broken him again to take an early 4-1 lead.

Baez will need to make more of an impact on serve if he is to prevent Draper running away with it.

There is a decent crowd at Court One to watch Jack Draper begin his Wimbledon campaign.

He has just made the perfect start, breaking Sebastian Baez to win the first game of the match.

Draper is widely considered Britain's great hope and the most likely home player to trouble the main contenders.

Can he make a winning start here? Or will he end up being the latest victim of another upset?

Iga Swiatek has admitted to smuggling towels out of every Grand Slam tournament due to floods of requests from her family and friends.

The Pole was pulled up by her Wimbledon interviewer for stacking her bag full after beating Polina Kudermetova on Tuesday, and her response was comical.

"Come on" she smiled. "It's a topic no one ever talks about. We love our towels. Every time I come back from a Slam I think I have like 10 friends and 10 family members wanting towels. So, sorry guys. Sorry Wimbledon. I don't know if I'm supposed to do that!"

Swiatek is only 24 but she turned professional almost a decade ago, and she has a huge amount of Grand Slam experience, having won four French Opens and two US Open titles. That, it turns out, has landed her and her loved ones more towels than they could ever have dreamed of.

"I have a lot at home," she added. "Trust me. I don't need many more. If I'm going play like 15 more years on tour I can't even imagine. I think I'm going to have to build another room in my house just for Grand Slam towels."



Wimbledon announced that they would be breaking protocol on Centre Court to allow today's losing player, Petra Kvitova, to address the crowd in an interview.

Kvitova lost to 10th seed Emma Navarro in her final ever match at SW19. She is retiring this year after the US Open.

The Czech icon won two titles at the All England Club in 2011 and 2014 and is recognised as one of the sport's greatest-ever players.

Martina Navratilova, her long-time rival, was in tears on BBC commentary and said: “It's hard for me to talk right now, she's just such a nice person on and off the court, a role model everywhere."

"This place holds the best memories I could wish for." \u2728Petra Kvitova says farewell to the #Wimbledon crowd pic.twitter.com/am0r3H16Iu

Here's a look at what's coming up on the main courts at Wimbledon tomorrow...

Centre Court (not before 1.30pm)

Aryna Sabalenka vs Marie Bouzkova

Oliver Tarvet vs Carlos Alcaraz

Emma Raducanu vs Marketa Vondrousova

Court One (not before 1pm)

Cameron Norrie vs Frances Tiafoe

Katie Boulter vs Solana Sierra

Taylor Fritz vs Gabriel Diallo

Dan Evans could face Novak Djokovic in the second round after winning an all-British affair with Jay Clarke.

And the 35-year-old is desperate for a potential blockbuster to be put on Centre Court, if Djokovic comes through his opener against Frenchman Alexandre Muller today.

"I would love it to be on Centre," he told the BBC. "That's it, that's all I ask. Just to get a chance to play him. I have played him before and it would be really nice to play Novak, who if he won't mind me saying is at the latter end of his career.

"And I really want to go out there and give it a good go. Because it's here, it's really special and for it to be in England against the greatest of all time."



There has been another upset on Court Three with reigning Olympic champion Qinwen Zheng falling at the first hurdle.

She has been beaten in three sets by Katerina Siniakova, who is unseeded.

Zheng would have been hoping for a deep run at SW19 but will instead be left to mull over what went wrong.

Dan Evans defeated fellow Brit Jay Clarke in straight sets, but the match was not without controversy.

Evans was accused by BBC commentators of using the “dark arts” to make his opponent “salty” during a tense second set.

Evans had won the first 6-1, but Clarke stepped his game up in the second and lost 7-5, after complaining to the umpire about his fellow Brit's conduct between serves.

Clarke asked the umpire about Evans “walking to the side and then walking back” before asking “is that normal?”

BBC commentator Dominic Inglot explained: "Dan Evans is a master of the dark arts, let's say, and he's used them extremely well there. You could say Jay Clarke is right, but on the flip side he has to be mentally tougher than that.

“He can't be falling for those little tricks. A few extra seconds is not the end of the world. Maybe a little bit salty there after getting broken."

Evans went on to seal his place in the second round for the first time in four years by taking the third set 6-2. A potential tie with Novak Djokovic awaits.

Last year's Wimbledon semi-finalist Lorenzo Musetti crashed out 12 months later in the first round to Georgian qualifier Nikoloz Basilashvili.

World No. 126 Basilashvili upset Musetti 6-2, 4-6, 7-5, 6-2 and secured his first-ever win at a Grand Slam.

And Musetti blamed his lack of preparation on grass.

"I was struggling to feel comfortable on the court from the beginning," he said.

"Even in the lateral movements, which normally I know how to move, seemed like I'd never played on this surface. It was a really bad performance."



No. 28 seed Alexander Bublik has just become the latest top player to suffer a massive upset in the first round.

The recent Halle champion was projected to meet British No. 1 Jack Draper in the third round - a rematch of their recent French Open clash, where Bublik sent the world No. 4 packing.

But Jaume Munar stunned the Kazakh in five sets, and Draper no longer has Bublik lurking in his section.

Stefanos Tsitsipas and Paula Badosa have fuelled rumours of a split by unfollowing each other on Instagram.

Tsitsipas has also seemingly removed all pictures of Badosa from his profile.

The couple went public with their relationship in 2023 before temporarily breaking up last summer.

They got back together just weeks later but there are now strong suggestions that they have gone their separate ways again.

Both players were off the boil at Wimbledon and lost in the first round on Monday.

They are still due to play together in the US Open mixed doubles event later this year.

Taylor Fritz was not happy last night after he was forced to end his match early with Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard last night.

The pair were into the final hour of play before the umpire called time and told both players to return for a fifth set the following day.

They did just that on Court 1.

And it was the American who came out on top by breaking his big-serving opponent in the final set and taking the first of his three match points.

Barbora Krejcikova has made a winning start to her Wimbledon title defence.

She beats Alexandra Eala in three sets, coming from behind to secure a 3-6 6-2 6-1 victory.

Krejcikova was made to work hard but ultimately did enough to win and book her place in the second round.



Wimbledon star Daria Kasatkina admitted that she was so nervous that she needed to throw up before her first-round match.

The Aussie defeated Emiliana Arango in straight sets, but she struggled before stepping onto Court 14 and had to vomit.

"I'm happy how I was able to manage those nerves because at the start of the day was very, very tough for me," she said. "The little accident happened completely out of nerves.

"There was nothing else wrong with me except this. Not having enough confidence, losing a couple of matches, the first match of the day….this doesn't help me to feel more calm.

"As soon as I stepped onto the court, it was much better. But before the match, I was so stressed, maybe too much."

Jannik Sinner admitted that he was surprised by the scorching heat at Wimbledon after beating Luca Nardi in straight sets.

In his on-court interview, he said: "I'm very, very happy to come back here. Playing against an Italian is very unfortunate but the atmosphere, as always, was amazing.

"I know it's very hot and humid, I don't remember the last time it was like this in London.

"We have worked a lot on the serve. I felt like I served very well in the important moments.

"I'm very happy with how I ended the match and hopefully that gives me the confidence to start the next match well."

Dan Evans has taken the first set against fellow Brit Jay Clarke.

And it was fairly straightforward, with the 35-year-old storming to a 6-1 victory in the opening exchanges.

He has since missed a break point in the second, however, and slapped his knee with his racket.

Clarke then saved another break point in a 17-shot rally and holds.



It's a comfortable final set for Sinner as he bagels Nardi and wins 6-4 6-3 6-0.

A much more seamless victory for the Italian than rival Carlos Alcaraz enjoyed.

Jannik Sinner started the second set with a hold, a break and then another hold to put him in the driving seat.

From there, he never relinquished control and won it 6-3.

He is two up and firmly in charge of this first-round match on Court 1.

Some very solid stuff being played by the top seed - the kind of tennis that should instil at least some fear in Carlos Alcaraz after his sloppy performance yesterday.

Two stars have already received medical timeouts in the opening hours today.

Katerina Siniakova has just received medication in her match against Qinwen Zheng, which is set to continue.

Meanwhile, Hamad Medjedovic has just been taken away from court to receive treatment on an injury that seems to be separate to the weather.

He trails Sebastian Offner 7-6.

A ball boy was replaced during Alex De Minaur's victory over Roberto Carballes Baena.

The reason for the change is said to have been due to the heat.

"We are just waiting for someone to replace a ball boy. They are not feeling well," said the umpire on Court 18.

Temperatures have exceeded 30 degrees celsius on a scorching hot day at the Championships.

Jannik Sinner is a set up on Court 1 after an opportune break of serve against Luca Nardi.

The Italian pair were level pegging throughout that first 48 minutes but Sinner turned it on at the perfect moment to notch a break in the 10th game and win 6-4.

A couple of Nardi mistakes helped the top seed but a majestic forehand down the line is what the crowd will take away.



Luca Nardi once joked that he was simply the "guy who beat Novak Djokovic".

The Italian, ranked 95th in the world, defeated Djokovic as lucky loser at last year's Indian Wells.

He will hope that even more people know his name after his clash with Jannik Sinner on Centre Court.

Yulia Putintseva called a spectator “dangerous” and “crazy” before suggesting that they could be carrying a knife.

Putintseva was beaten 6-0 6-0 by Amanda Anisimova yesterday and, midway through the first set, she alerted an individual to the umpire.

She asked the umpire: “Can you take him out? I'm not going to continue playing until he leaves. These people are dangerous, they're crazy. Maybe he has a knife and he will attack after, I don't know.”

Wimbledon say a situation on court was dealt with.

We're pushing 32 degrees Celsius on Court 1 and it's sweltering even in the shade.

Lord knows how Jannik Sinner and Luca Nardi are feeling in the direct sunlight. Scared, probably.

The heat got the better of a few players yesterday.

Top seed Sinner will hope he doesn't suffer the same fate today.

It's an all-Italian clash to get him going, and I'm sure he'll want to be back under the AC as soon as possible.

The No. 4 seed will start his quest for glory in his home Grand Slam when he faces Sebastian Baez.

United wished him well on X, posting: "British no.1 Jack Draper kicks off his #Wimbledon campaign later today! Wishing you the best of luck, Jack."

Elisabetta Cocciaretto has revealed that she was in hospital during Wimbledon last year.

The Italian is the latest underdog to take down a seeded star in the first round this time around, sensationally beating Jessica Pegula in straight sets.

Cocciaretto said on court: “For sure I played with a player like her before, Iga [Swiatek], Aryna [Sabalenka], all of those players that you have to do the best you can on the court and take the little chances they give you.

“I tried to do the opposite to what I did in the other matches. To be more aggressive, to go for it and don't think about winning or losing the point, just do your best. I think I did a great job today and I'm super happy about that.

“I had a lot of stops last year. I was in hospital and I was sick for one month and I couldn't play here. That's why I was so pumped to play because I think it's the best tournament and grass is always special to play.

“I don't think too much about my ranking right now. With the ranking, you can play other tournaments. The journey of tennis is so long and up and down always. You have to adapt yourself and enjoy and accept what happens in life.”

Nick Kyrgios has cheekily suggested that Emma Raducanu is in a 'love triangle' with Carlos Alcaraz and Jack Draper.

Raducanu and Alcaraz have been the subject of romance rumours ahead of their upcoming mixed doubles partnership at the US Open, although the British women's No. 1 insists their relationship is purely platonic.

Some Alcaraz fans feared that Kyrgios might be trying to muscle in when he left a supportive comment on one of Raducanu's recent Instagram posts. The Aussie, who is working for talkSPORT after being dropped by the BBC, was asked on Tuesday for his take on the obsession with Raducanu's love life.

And he jokingly responded: "I don't know, I think it's a love triangle! Draper, Alcaraz, Raducanu. They're fighting over Raducanu I think, I'm not sure."



Harriet Dart has partially blamed the heat on her first-round defeat against Dalma Galfi.

The British star lost in three sets and argued that the home favourites are not well equipped to deal with the blazing temperatures, which are set to exceed 30 degrees celsius this week.

“It was challenging but it's the same for everyone,” she said. “I don't think I've played a match where it was this hot on grass.

“We're not very well equipped in this country to deal with it, so it becomes more of a shock. I've played in hotter places but here it's a shock because even when you go inside it's still pretty warm, so you can't escape it.

“It was difficult with half the sun on the court and half of it in shade. I was slow to adapt to seeing the ball but she served really well, particularly in big moments.”

The daughter of the spectator who was taken ill during Carlos Alcaraz's Wimbledon first-round win against Fabio Fognini has thanked the Spaniard on social media.

Alcaraz's five-set victory on Centre Court was suspended during the decider as medical personnel attended to a fan.

The reigning two-time champion quickly provided assistance by rushing over with a water bottle before the spectator was guided out of the stands.

This morning, the fan's daughter took to social media to show Alcaraz her gratitude after his actions.

Eluned Lewis wrote on X: "Thank you @carlosalcaraz for the concern shown to my mum today, who was taken ill during your tennis match at Centre Court @Wimbledon today. Unlikely you'll see this message, but I can try! Thank you @BBCSport."

Novak Djokovic is about to begin his bid for Wimbledon glory against a tennis star with an unusual sponsorship deal.

And while Alexandre Muller insists that his affiliation with OnlyFans is not exactly what it seems, the 28-year-old still refers to himself as 'the sexiest professional tennis player from France'.

Muller said in an interview with The Sun: "[OnlyFans] wants to change their image. They are supporting lots of players, golfers, boxers, UFC fighters... a lot of sportsmen.

"At the beginning my friends were laughing at me. Then I showed them my platform and they said: ‘OK, it's very cool.' Everybody wants to sign up now.

"Do I post risque photos? No, no. I don't do it. Because I don't want to. My job is a tennis player, not making movies for adults. I received a lot of messages, saying: ‘Alex, can you show me this?' But not my body."



John McEnroe bluntly described Carlos Alcaraz as looking as 'flat as a pancake' at Wimbledon.

Alcaraz made hard work of a five-set victory over Fabio Fognini.

McEnroe believes it was a 'wake-up call' for the Spaniard.

Speaking on the BBC, the three-time former champion said: “Carlos looked as flat as a pancake. Why? I don't know. Perhaps he assumed this Fognini would fall away pretty quickly.

"His serve was off, his forehand… to see him play like that was surprising. You've got to give Fognini credit, but he was up a set and 4-2. He should have won the second set.

“He was up 4-2 or 5-3 in the third and he barely pulled that set out. He got blown out in the fourth. It's a good wake-up call for him. He won Queen's, everything was perfect, same as last year.

"He won the French Open, pulls out an incredible match [against Jannik Sinner], parties in Ibiza with his buddies, comes to Queen's and almost loses early, but goes on and wins it. Perhaps it's going to be similar here.”



We are underway on day two at Wimbledon, with lots of matches getting started at 11am.

Great Britain's Heather Watson is currently in action against Denmark's Clara Tauson on BBC Two.

Elsewhere, British wildcard Johannus Monday has started his tough test against world No. 13 Tommy Paul.

Sonay Kartal successfully sought revenge over 20th seed Jelena Ostapenko at Wimbledon.

The British star defeated Ostapenko in three sets, a mere few days after losing to the Latvian in Eastbourne.

“I felt great coming into it, so to get that kind of win, I've got masses of confidence,” Kartal said.

“I don't think that I could have done too much better at times in that match. I feel like this is the best I've ever played on grass. It's the most confident I've also got in my game. I think I'm in a pretty good spot for round two.”



Daniil Medvedev admits he is suffering from a lack of confidence after crashing out of Wimbledon in round one yesterday.

The Russian had already exited the Australian Open in the second round and French Open at the first hurdle.

And he lost to world No. 64 Benjamin Bonzi in four sets at SW19 to continue his nightmare run.

“For me, it's a matter of confidence. If not for the results in Halle, I would be here and say something is definitely missing. It's just a matter of a couple of matches," Medvedev reacted.

"This year, I lost a lot of close calls. When I start winning them, I can climb up the rankings. For the moment, I'm not that worried.

"If I finish the year ranked somewhere around No. 15 in the world, maybe I'll be more worried. For the moment, I'm not."

Yulia Putintseva asked the chair umpire to remove a 'crazy' spectator during her first-round defeat at Wimbledon on Monday.

The Kazakhstani was only on court for 44 minutes as she was thrashed 6-0 6-0 by Amanda Anisimova.

An All England Club spokesperson later said: "Following a complaint about the behaviour of a spectator at the match on Court 15, the chair umpire informed security and the matter was dealt with."

Wimbledon have been urged to ditch their strict all-white kit policy.

The rules were tightened in the mid 1990s to dictate that all players must wear all-white kit on court, including tracksuits and other clothing.

Women have since been told they can wear dark undershorts to prevent anxiety during their menstrual cycles.

Billie Jean King believes the 1995 rule change was a "total mistake" and says television viewers struggle to tell players apart during matches.

She told the Telegraph: “There's a match that comes on, you sit down, and you look – let's say it's television – who's who?

“Tennis people say: ‘Well, the mark is next to their name' [to indicate who is serving]. I shouldn't have to look at a mark, I shouldn't have to look at anything. I should know [who's who]. My sport drives me nuts.”

Jack Draper can go all the way and win his first Grand Slam at this year's Wimbledon, claims 1994 champion Conchita Martinez.

“He's number four in the world, so he's already there. He's up with the top players," Martinez told BoyleSports.

“He's a great guy, and he won the men's title at Indian Wells when Mirra won the women's title, and we saw what he was like practising on the court. He has a great level of focus.

“You can tell when a player really wants it. He is very professional. I didn't see him play a lot, but then you pay attention, and he can play on any surface. He is already there; he's beaten top players.

“Carlos and Jannik are a bit ahead of Jack. He needs to be consistent the whole year. He needs to be consistent from the baseline to play against these guys. Jack has the game to go to the net and be aggressive, but you're up against two guys who can produce amazing shots.

“Jack has a very good chance of making the semi-finals at Wimbledon. Once you get to the semi-finals, why not go all the way? I think Alcaraz will be suitable for Jack's game. He has the potential to go all the way.”



Rising British star Oliver Tarvet has theoretically banked £99,000 at Wimbledon this year.

But rather harsh circumstances mean the qualifier will not see most of that money following a run that will see him meet Carlos Alcaraz in round two.

Tarvet, 21, is the lowest-ranked player in the singles draw at world No. 733. He still attends to San Diego University and intends to complete his final year.

His amateur status combined with American college rules mean Tarvet is only allowed to claim £7,290 as his own, in addition to genuine tennis expenses - which will at least allow him to enter more prestige tournaments than before.

The rest of the money is paid to his university.

Tarvet joked: “I've got to find £60,000 – £70,000 of expenses – tennis is an expensive sport.

“I hope to get the prize money and use that money as expenses. I will try and do everything I can to make that work out and to find X amount of expenses so I'm under $10,000 of profit.

"[It's] something I've got to figure out. Maybe I will hire someone to help me out with the expenses, make sure the NCAA are happy. It's very important for me. I have a lot of goals at USD still.”

Nick Kyrgios has backed Coco Gauff to progress beyond the Wimbledon fourth round for the first time ever this summer.

The 21-year-old has two Grand Slams to her name but has never enjoyed a long run in SW19.

Kyrgios believes that should change in the coming weeks.

"She has an incredible backhand and she's an incredible athlete,” Kyrgios told talkSPORT.

“The grass is a little bit faster. It's a faster surface, and I think her forehand swing sometimes can get a bit large on the grass and catch it a bit late.

“But you look at some of the results that she's had over the last six months, and I think confidence-wise she's fixed those existing problems on a second serve as well.

“She had those problems where she was double-faulting a lot. She had a bit of the yips on a second serve.

“So I think she's fixed those, and I think you know serving at Wimbledon is the most important thing. You have to be serving well to win Wimbledon.”

John McEnroe has told Fabio Fognini to retire after his defeat against Carlos Alcaraz.

Fognini, 38, was playing in his 15th Wimbledon and recently hinted that he was going to step away from the tour.

He took two sets from the world No. 2 and was backed by the majority of the Centre Court crowd.

"This was the perfect ending for Fognini," McEnroe told the BBC.

"Luckily for Alcaraz, towards the end of the fourth set, the crowd realised that Fognini was playing unbelievable. Carlos looked more tired than Fognini even though there's a 16-year age gap! What in the hell is going on here?

"So the crowd started rallying behind Alcaraz and that picked him up a little bit. I almost hope that [Fognini] doesn't play anymore because I'm not sure he can play any better than that.

"I played [Fognini's wife] Flavio Panetta in seniors mixed doubles at the French [Open] and she thinks it's time for Fabio to be at home more with the kids. I think she is ready for her husband to be home more."



Wimbledon could face chaos today with suspended matches added to the updated order of play.

Several matches were halted before the 11pm curfew last night, including those involving Alexander Zverev and Taylor Fritz.

Those matches have been added to their respective courts in the second slot of the day.

It leaves bosses with a potential headache as some courts are set to host up to five matches.

Centre Court will have four ties, the same as yesterday. Court No. 3 will host five.

Novak Djokovic has been given a brutal reality check ahead of his Wimbledon campaign.

It is widely accepted that Wimbledon provides the Serb's final opportunity to land a coveted 25th Grand Slam title.

But former tennis star Feliciano Lopez says Djokovic is not on the same level as rivals Carlos Alcaraz and Jannik Sinner anymore.

“He's not at the levels of Carlos and Jannik, especially in the last 18 months, because the numbers speak for themselves,” the three-time Wimbledon quarter-finalist told Sky Sports.

“Although the gap is still big, I see the grass as the only place for him to get to this level that they play because the grass is very different.

“Djokovic proved that he can still compete at this level but he will have a better chance on grass.”

Taylor Fritz fumed at a Wimbledon umpire after his match was suspended at around 10.20pm yesterday.

Wimbledon's curfew is not until 11pm but Fritz's clash with Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard was halted 40 minutes prior.

The American had just battled back to win the fourth set and send the match into a deciding set.

To a chorus of boos, Fritz ranted at the umpire, believing there was more than enough time for a final set to take place.

Their match will resumed today.



Never at Wimbledon have seven Brits all won on the same day.

It is testament to the strength of the British game that the country has so many top players in the first round this year.

Katie Boulter saw off ninth seed Paula Badosa on Centre Court, while Emma Raducanu defeated Mimi Xu in an all-British clash.

Sonay Kartal beat 20th-seed Jelena Ostapenko in immediate revenge for her Eastbourne loss.

Oliver Tarvet continued his remarkable as a qualifier, winning as the No. 733-ranked player in the world.

Arthur Fery, Cam Norrie and Billy Harris all progressed.

Hello and welcome back to Express Sport's coverage of Wimbledon.

Alexander Zverev will head into day two of Wimbledon on a level playing field with Arthur Rinderknech.

The German wins a second-set tiebreak before play is suspended for the night ahead of the 11pm curfew.

The two players will resume their first-round battle tomorrow with everything still to play for.

Former tennis star Todd Woodbridge believes that Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard should be over the moon with the decision to suspend his Wimbledon first-round clash with Taylor Fritz.

The big-serving Frenchman had just lost two sets on the bounce when match officials opted to call it off and pick it back up tomorrow with the 11pm curfew closing in.

With the scores at two sets apiece, Woodbridge said: "I'm a little surprised by that decision. I think the referee has come out too early, he could've given them the option. We still had 45 minutes to go to curfew.

"The sets that we had have all been under 45 minutes, they've been close to it but there was definitely the chance of an outcome there tonight.

"I think Mpetshi Perricard, good for him, he should get off and be very happy with that. Taylor Fritz will be a little annoyed by that decision I have no doubt because he played an exceptional tiebreak from 5-1 down to hang in."

The match between Taylor Fritz and Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard has been suspended for the night in bizarre fashion.

It caused frustration in the crowd, with many fans booing the announcement which came 40 minutes before the 11pm curfew.

Fritz, who had just edged a fourth-set tiebreak to force a deciding set, was also left raging with the decision.

He was well within his rights to be upset, given that there would probably have been enough time for the match to reach a conclusion.

Spare a thought for the paying ticket-holders who have seemingly been denied the full value of their money.



Holger Rune was left frustrated after throwing away a two-set lead against Nicolas Jarry earlier today.

The Dane was in control until the return of a troublesome knee injury saw him slip to a 4-6 4-6 7-5 6-3 6-4 loss.

After the match, Rune had some interesting words for Jarry while discussing his defeat.

He said: "If I play normal, I'm beating him nine out of ten times, with all respect for Nicolas Jarry.

"I'm going to check now with the head doctor and physio and will take it from there.

"I don't know if it's worse now, or better, or the same. It needs to be examined."

Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard broke a long-standing Wimbledon record during his match against Taylor Fritz.

The towering Frenchman, who stands at six feet and eight inches tall, pulled off thunderous services of 151mph and 153mph.

It saw him surpass the previous benchmark of 148mph, which was set by Taylor Dent back in 2010.

Mpetshi Perricard currently leads Fritz by two sets to one, with his American opponent battling to avoid an early exit.

John McEnroe wants Fabio Fognini to retire following his spirited defeat to Carlos Alcaraz on Monday.

The Italian is in the midst of his final season as a professional and McEnroe thinks that his last outing at Wimbledon would be the ideal note on which to end his career.

"This was the perfect ending for Fognini," the American told the BBC. "Luckily for Alcaraz, towards the end of the fourth set, the crowd realised that Fognini was playing unbelievable. Carlos looked more tired than Fognini even though there's a 16-year age gap! What in the hell is going on here?

"So the crowd started rallying behind Alcaraz and that picked him up a little bit. I almost hope that [Fognini] doesn't play anymore because I'm not sure he can play any better than that.

"I played [Fognini's wife] Flavio Panetta in seniors mixed doubles at the French [Open] and she thinks it's time for Fabio to be at home more with the kids. I think she is ready for her husband to be home more."



Play on the outdoor courts has been suspended for poor light.

Botic van de Zandschulp led Matteo Arnaldi by two tiebreak sets on Court 12 when they had to stop.

And Shintaro Mochizuki had just forced a fifth and final set against Giulio Zeppieri when their match was abandoned for the night.

With seven wins in the singles, it has been the most successful day for British players at Wimbledon in the Open era.

As well as Boulter, there were victories for Cameron Norrie, Arthur Fery, Sonay Kartal, Emma Raducanu, Oliver Tarvet and Billy Harris.

Some of those were huge upsets and it remains to be seen how the British contingent will fare in the second round.

There has been ANOTHER huge upset at Wimbledon and this time it's courtesy of Katie Boulter.

She beats Paula Badosa in three sets to become the seventh Briton to reach the second round.

It's been a brilliant opening day for the home contingent and Boulter looks delighted after securing her own surprise victory.

She will go up against Solana Sierra in her next match on Wednesday.

Nick Kyrgios was spotted in Naomi Osaka's box to watch her beat Talia Gibson earlier today.

The outspoken Aussie is due to link up with Osaka in the mixed doubles tournament at the US Open later this year.

He would have been impressed with the relatively straightforward manner of her 6-4 7-6 victory on Court 18.
